title: What are the different classifications in the animal kingdom? - Quora

response.answer_text: An offensively simplified list would be this (biased towards vertebrates, due to my education) Poirifera (sponges) Cnidara (jellyfish, anemones, coral) Flatworms Molluscs (snails, mussels, cephalopods) Segmented worms Arthropods (arachnids, insects, crustaceans, etc) Echinoderms (starfish, sea urchins, sea cucumbers, etc) Tunicates (sea squirts, etc) Vertebrates Within vertebrates, you have: Jawless fish (lampreys, etc) Cartilaginous fish (sharks, rays) Ray finned fish (salmon, tuna, carp, etc) Lobe finned fish (coelocanths, lungfish) Amphibians Amniotes, which split into two groups: First, synapsids: Various groups of extinct, cold-blooded “mammal-like reptiles", exemplified by Dimetrodon and Edaphosaurus Therapsids (dicynodonts, gorgonopsids, cynodonts, mammals, etc) Within mammals: Monotremes (platypus, echidna) Marsupials (kangaroo, koala, etc) Afrotherians (elephants, manatees, hyraxes, aardvarks, tenrecs, etc) Boreoeutheria (primates, hoofed mammals, rodents, whales, carnivores, insectivores, bats, etc) Xenarthrans (sloths, armadillos, anteaters) And, second, Sauropsids: Various groups of semiaquatic or lizard like reptiles, eg Mesosaurus Lepidosauromorphs (lizards, snakes, tuataras, presumably sauropterygians [sea reptiles]) Archosauromorphs (archosaurs and presumably turtles) Within archosaurs: Phytosaurs (crocodile-like Triassic reptiles) Erythrosuchians (large-headed crocodile-like reptiles) Pseudosuchians (true crocodiles and their closest extinct relatives) Avemetatarsalians (pterosaurs, dinosaurs [inc. birds], silesaurs)

Too complex to answer, as there is no agreement on the number of phyla. Some say 30, some say 36… below is further reading for you with extra links by noted scientists on this subject : Encyclopedia of Life Animal Phyla Last updated over 1 year ago The major subgroups of animals are usually classified as phyla (singular: phylum). The higher classification of animals is still in flux, and scientists' opinions on which groups should be given phylum status change as new information about the structure of the animal tree of life becomes available. So you may see that some of the groups listed here as phyla are classified differently elsewhere. For example, the spiny-headed worms, Acanthocephala used to be treated as a phylum, but research has shown that this group is probably nested within the phylum Rotifera, so it will probably disappear from modern lists of animal phyla.
